title: Introduction to Mathematical Methods for Physics
description: Provides the applied mathematics and problem solving/presentation skills necessary for success in an introductory physics sequence. Focuses on practical exercises in problem solving. Covers kinematics in one and two dimensions in detail. Additional topics include vectors, differentiation, and integration.
restriction: PHYSICS 2 may not be taken for credit if taken after PHYSICS 7C.
prerequisite or corequisite: MATH 2A or MATH 5A or AP Calculus AB or AP Calculus BC. AP Calculus AB with a minimum score of 4. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 3

title: Basic Physics I
description: Vectors; motion, force, and energy.
restriction: PHYSICS 3A may not be taken for credit if taken after PHYSICS 7C.
corequisite: MATH 2A or MATH 5A, or a score of 4 or higher on the AP Calculus AB exam, or a score of 3 or higher on the AP Calculus BC exam.

title: Basic Physics II
description: Fluids; heat; electricity and magnetism.
prerequisite: PHYSICS 3A or AP Physics C: Mechanics. AP Physics C: Mechanics with a minimum score of 5

title: Basic Physics III
description: Waves and sound; optics; quantum ideas; atomic and nuclear physics; relativity.
prerequisite: PHYSICS 3A or AP Physics C: Mechanics. AP Physics C: Mechanics with a minimum score of 5
corequisite: MATH 2B or MATH 5B, or a score of 4 or higher on the AP Calculus BC exam.

title: Basic Physics Laboratory
description: Practical applications of electronics and classical physics to biology. Goals include skill to use oscilloscope and other basic instrumentation. Materials fee.

title: Basic Physics Laboratory
description: Practical applications of physics to medical imaging.  Topics include optics, radioactivity, and acoustics. Materials fee.

title: Classical Physics
description: Topics include force, energy, momentum, rotation, and gravity.
prerequisite: PHYSICS 2 or (MATH 2D and (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C) or CHEM M2C) or AP Physics C: Mechanics or AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism or SAT Mathematics or ACT Mathematics. PHYSICS 2 with a grade of C or better. AP Physics C: Mechanics with a minimum score of 4. AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism with a minimum score of 4. SAT Mathematics with a minimum score of 650. ACT Mathematics with a minimum score of 27. Recommended: One year of high school physics or equivalent physics background.
restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.
corequisite: MATH 2B or AP CALCULUS BC, min score = 4.

title: Classical Physics
description: Electricity and magnetism.
prerequisite: PHYSICS 7C and (MATH 2B or AP Calculus BC). AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4
restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Classical Physics
description: Fluids; oscillations; waves; and optics.
restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Classical Physics Laboratory
description: Experiments related to lecture topics in Physics 7C. Materials fee.
restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Classical Physics Laboratory
description: Electricity and magnetism.
restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Science Fiction and Science Fact
description: An introduction to fundamental physics principles, the scientific process, and the mathematical language of science, used to analyze topics drawn from superheroes, science fiction works, and current science news to distinguish science fiction and science fact.

title: Energy and the Environment
description: The physics of society's energy production and consumption, and of their influences on the environment. Topics include fossil and renewable energy resources; nuclear power; prospects for a hydrogen economy; efficient and environmentally benign transportation; efficient home and commercial energy usage.

title: Physics of Music
description: Introduces basic physical principles underlying generation and properties of music, including basic properties of sound waves, musical scales and temperament, musical instruments, and acoustics of music halls.  No mathematics background required, but high school algebra is recommended.

title: Physics of Athletics
description: Introduces basic physical principles behind motion. Examples are drawn from a range of athletic endeavors (such as ice skating, baseball, diving, and dance). No mathematics background required, but high school algebra is recommended.

title: How Things Work
description: Survey of the physical basis of modern technology, with an emphasis on electronics and materials. Topics include power generation and distribution, communication (radio, TV, telephone, computers, tape recorders, CD players), imaging (optics, x-rays, MRI), and modern materials (alloys, semiconductors, superconductors).

title: Great Ideas of Physics
description: Introduces non-science majors to physics, examining important breakthroughs and controversies. Potential topics: Einstein's Relativity; Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle; black holes; extra-dimensions; antimatter. Case studies illustrate the essential nature of scientific review and independent confirmation of results. No mathematics background required.

title: Introduction to Astronomy
description: History of astronomy. Underlying physics. Objects in the solar system and how they are studied. Properties of stars: their formation, structure, and evolution. Pulsars and black holes. Galaxies and quasars.

title: Cosmology: Humanity's Place in the Universe
description: An overview of the origin, evolution, and ultimate fate of the Universe. Galaxies and dark matter. The Big Bang and dark energy.  Ancient world models.

title: Space Science
description: Space exploration. Human missions to the moon, Mars, and beyond. Space stations, observatories, and deep-space probes. Robots and drones on distant worlds. Propulsion mechanisms, rockets, space flight, and the dangers of solar radiation.

title: Life in the Universe
description: An overview of the scientific quest to discover life elsewhere in the universe. Topics include the origin of life on Earth, Mars, extra-solar planets, interstellar travel, and extra-terrestrial intelligence.

title: Special Topics in Physics
description: Topics addressed vary each quarter. Past topics have included physics and music, Newton, planetary science. Lectures on areas of special interest in physics used to introduce students to scientific method, fundamental laws of science, qualitative and quantitative analysis of data.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

title: Introductory Mathematical Physics
description: Introduction to math methods for upper-division physics. Taylor and Fourier series; complex algebra; ordinary differential equations; matrices, tensors and vector spaces; eigensystems; orthogonal coordinates; vector calculus and fields. Symbolic computation with Mathematica is incorporated through-out.
restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Modern Physics
description: Wave-particle duality; quantum mechanics; special relativity; statistical mechanics.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics
description: Optics: lenses, mirrors, polarization, lasers, optical fibers, interference, spectra. Materials fee.
restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics
description: Circuits: oscilloscope, meters, DC and AC circuits. Materials fee.
restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics
description: Data analysis: random and systematic errors, curve fitting; nuclear counting; quantum experiments. Error analysis: random and systematic errors, curve fitting, nuclear counting, and quantum experiments. Materials fee.
restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Introduction to Programming and Numerical Analysis
description: Introduction to structured programming; in-depth training in python. Elementary numerical methods applied to physics problems.
restriction: Physics Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Thermal Physics
description: Introduction to thermodynamics and systems of many particles. Topics include first and second laws of thermodynamics, ideal gas laws, kinetic theory, heat engines and refrigerators, thermodynamic potentials, phase transitions, dilute solutions, chemical equilibrium, and basic statistical distributions.

title: Modern Physics for Majors
description: Wave-particle duality; Schrodinger equation; angular momentum.

title: Modern Physics for Majors
description: Atomic transitions; molecules; solids; nuclei; elementary particles; cosmological models.

title: Introduction to Astrophysics
description: Introduction to fundamental topics in astrophysics, including stellar structure and evolution; stellar remnants; detection and characterization of exoplanets; physics of interstellar gas and star-forming regions.

title: Impact of World War I on Science
description: Introduction to science in 1914 and WWI. Participants in groups of two or three will pick a preferred science; find out what happened to it during and after the war; write reports and present what they learned.

title: The Idiom and Practice of Science
description: A series of fundamental and applied scientific problems of social relevance. Possible topics include Newton's Law, calculus, earthquake physics, and radiation.

title: Current Topics in Physics
description: Designed to introduce undergraduate students to current topics in physics. Focus is discussion of selected readings on current research issues.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

title: Computational Methods
description: Mathematical and numerical analysis using Mathematica and C programming, as applied to problems in physical science.

title: Advanced Data Acquisition, Analysis, and Scientific Writing
description: Introduces modern practical laboratory techniques for developing data interface devices, acquiring and analyzing data, and writing up results in manuscript format. Experiments include interfacing with instruments through software and hardware development, PID controller, Fourier analysis, and lock-in amplifier.

title: Classical Mechanics
description: One-dimensional motion and oscillations; three-dimensional motion, non-inertial coordinates, conservation laws, and Lagrangian and Hamiltonian dynamics; rigid body motion and relativity.

title: Classical Mechanics
description: One-dimensional motion and oscillations; three-dimensional motion, non-inertial coordinates, conservation laws, and Lagrangian and Hamiltonian dynamics; rigid body motion and relativity.

title: Electromagnetic Theory
description: Electric, magnetic, and gravitational fields and potentials; electrodynamics; mechanical and electromagnetic waves and radiation.

title: Electromagnetic Theory
description: Electric, magnetic, and gravitational fields and potentials; electrodynamics; mechanical and electromagnetic waves and radiation.

title: Quantum Physics
description: Inadequacy of classical physics; time independent and time dependent Schrodinger equation; systems in one, two, and three dimensions; matrices; Hermitian operators; symmetries; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory; applications to atomic structure; emphasis on phenomenology.

title: Quantum Physics
description: Inadequacy of classical physics; time independent and time dependent Schrodinger equation; systems in one, two, and three dimensions; matrices; Hermitian operators; symmetries; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory; applications to atomic structure; emphasis on phenomenology.

title: Quantum Physics
description: Inadequacy of classical physics; time independent and time dependent Schrodinger equation; systems in one, two, and three dimensions; matrices; Hermitian operators; symmetries; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory; applications to atomic structure; emphasis on phenomenology.

title: Statistical Physics
description: Microscopic theory of temperature, heat, and entropy; kinetic theory; multicomponent systems; quantum statistics.
prerequisite: PHYSICS 50 and (PHYSICS 60 or CHEM 1C or ENGRMAE 91)

title: Relativity and Black Holes
description: Introduces students to both special and general relativity; includes the formalism of four-vectors, equivalence principle, curved space-time, and modern issues with black holes.

title: Electronics for Scientists
description: Applications of modern semiconductor devices to physical instrumentation. Characteristics of semiconductor devices, integrated circuits, analog and digital circuits. Materials fee.

title: Advanced Laboratory
description: Experiments in atomic, condensed matter, nuclear, particle, and plasma physics. Introduction to instrumentation and a first experience in the research laboratory.
prerequisite: (PHYSICS 51B or PHYSICS 61B or PHYSICS 61C) and (PHYSICS 52C or PHYSICS 193) and (PHYSICS 194 or EDUC 143BW)
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.

title: Mathematical Physics
description: Complex variables; Legendre and Bessel functions; complete sets of orthogonal functions; partial differential equations; integral equations; calculus of variations; coordinate transformations; special functions and series.

title: Mathematical Physics
description: Complex variables; Legendre and Bessel functions; complete sets of orthogonal functions; partial differential equations; integral equations; calculus of variations; coordinate transformations; special functions and series.

title: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics
description: Phenomena of solids and their interpretation in terms of quantum theory.

title: Physical and Geometrical Optics
description: Focuses on the practical aspects of optics and optical engineering, starting at the fundamentals. Topics include geometrical optics, ray tracing, polarization optics, interferometers, and diffractive optics.

title: Plasma Physics
description: Basic concepts, orbits, kinetic and fluid equations, Coulomb collisions, fluctuations, scattering, radiation.

title: Introduction to Particle Physics
description: Experimental techniques and theoretical concepts of high-energy phenomena: accelerators and detectors; classification of particles and interactions; particle properties; symmetries and mass multiplets; production and decay mechanisms.

title: Introduction to Cosmology
description: Solution of the differential equations governing the expansion of the Universe. Observational determinations of the parameters governing the expansion. Big Bang inflation, primordial nucleosynthesis, and cosmic microwave background. Dark matter, dark energy, and large-scale structure of the Universe.

title: Astrophysics of Galaxies
description: Introduction to the solar neighborhood, Milky Way, and other galaxies. Interstellar medium. Star formation. Stellar populations. Evolution of spiral, elliptical, and irregular galaxies. Supermassive black holes, quasars, and active galaxies. Galaxies as probes of the expansion rate of the Universe.

title: Observational Astrophysics
description: Telescopes and astronomical observations, imaging with CCD detectors and image processing techniques. Photometry and spectroscopy of stars, galaxies, and quasars. Advanced imaging techniques such as deconvolution, adaptive optics, and interferometry.
prerequisite: PHYSICS 52A and PHYSICS 52B and PHYSICS 52C and PHYSICS 53

title: Stellar Astrophysics
description: Stars: their structure and evolution; physical state of the interior; the Hertzprung- Russell diagram, stellar classification, and physical principles responsible for the classification; star formation; nuclear burning; giant and dwarf stars; neutron stars and black holes.
prerequisite: (PHYSICS 51A or PHYSICS 61A) and PHYSICS 111A and PHYSICS 112A

title: High-Energy Astrophysics
description: Production of radiation by high-energy particles, white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Evolution of galactic nuclei, radio galaxies, quasars, and pulsars.  Cosmic rays and the cosmic background radiation.
prerequisite: (PHYSICS 51A or PHYSICS 61A) and PHYSICS 111A and PHYSICS 112A

title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

title: Techniques in Medical Imaging I: X-ray, Nuclear, and NMR Imaging
description: Ionizing radiation, planar and tomographic radiographic and nuclear imaging, magnetism, NMR, MRI imaging.

title: Techniques in Medical Imaging II: Ultrasound, Electrophysiological, Optical
description: Sound and ultrasound, ultrasonic imaging, physiological electromagnetism, EEG, MEG, ECG, MCG, optical properties of tissues, fluorescence and bioluminescence, MR impedance imaging, MR spectroscopy, electron spin resonance and ESR imaging.

title: Special Topics in Physics and Astronomy
description: Current topics in physics.  Includes topics from nano-science, biological sciences, astrophysics, and the common use of estimation across subdisciplines within physics.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

title: Field Experience in Physics Education
description: Students develop and perform physics assemblies at neighboring public schools.
repeatability: May be taken for credit for 8 units.

title: Tutoring in Physics
description: Formalizes the already existing free tutoring for the lower-division physics courses that is provided by the Society of Physics Students (SPS). Includes instructions on tutoring techniques.
restriction: Society of Physics Students (SPS) tutoring program students only.
repeatability: May be taken for credit for 12 units.

title: Research Methods
description: Explores tools of inquiry for developing and implementing science research projects.  Students undertake independent projects requiring data collection, analysis, and modeling, and the organization and presentation of results.  Additional topics include ethical issues and role of scientific literature.

title: Research Communication for Physics Majors
description: Students learn the fundamentals of communicating about research. Topics include preparing abstracts, proposals, and literature reviews. Provides preparation for presentation of independent research projects in PHYSICS 121 and PHYSICS 196.
prerequisite: PHYSICS 61A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.

title: Undergraduate Research
description: Independent research under the guidance of a Physics faculty member.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Thesis in Physics I
description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students' research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

title: Thesis in Physics II
description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students' research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

title: Thesis in Physics III
description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students' research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

title: Honors Thesis in Physics I
description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students' research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
restriction: Physics Majors only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Honors Program in Physics students only.

title: Honors Thesis in Physics II
description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students' research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
restriction: Physics Majors only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Honors Program in Physics students only.

title: Honors Thesis in Physics III
description: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students' research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.
restriction: Physics Majors only. Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. Honors Program in Physics students only.

title: Readings on Special Topics
description: Readings in selected areas of Physics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Advanced Data Acquisition and Analysis
description: Introduces students to a variety of practical laboratory techniques, including lock-in, boxcar, coincidence counting, noise filtering, PID control, properties of common transducers, computer interfacing to instruments, vacuum technology, laboratory safety, basic mechanical design, and shop skills. Materials fee.

title: Applied Physical Chemistry
description: Introduction to fundamental concepts in molecular structure and reactivity: theory of bonding, valence and molecular orbitals; structure and reactivity in inorganic chemistry; elements in molecular group theory; nomenclature in organic chemistry; and survey of macromolecules.

title: Math Methods
description: Applications of mathematics to physical and chemical problems. Calculus of special functions, complex variables and vectors; linear vector spaces and eigenvalue problems. Differential equations.

title: Classical Mechanics
description: Variational principles, Lagrange's equations; applications to two body problems, small oscillation theory, and other phenomena. Hamilton's equations. Hamilton-Jacobi theory. Canonical transformations.

title: Mathematical Physics
description: Complex variables and integration; ordinary and partial differential equations; the eigenvalue problem.

title: Electromagnetic Theory
description: Electrostatics; magnetostatics; relativity; classical electron theory; fields in vacuum and matter; retardation; radiation and absorption; dispersion; propagation of light; diffraction; geometric optics; theories of the electric and magnetic properties of materials; scattering.

title: Electromagnetic Theory
description: Electrostatics; magnetostatics; relativity; classical electron theory; fields in vacuum and matter; retardation; radiation and absorption; dispersion; propagation of light; diffraction; geometric optics; theories of the electric and magnetic properties of materials; scattering.

title: Statistical Physics
description: Maxwell-Boltzmann, Bose-Einstein, Fermi-Dirac statistics; ideal and imperfect gases; thermodynamic properties of solids; transport theory.

title: Many Body Theory
description: Application of field theory methods, perturbative and non-perturbative, to many particle systems; second quantization, Feynman diagrams, linear response theory, and functional integral methods applied to the ground state and at finite temperature.

title: Quantum Mechanics
description: Foundations; Dirac notation; basic operators and their eigenstates; perturbation theory; spin.

title: Quantum Mechanics
description: Atomic physics; scattering theory, formal collision theory; semi-classical radiation theory; many body systems.

title: Electronics for Scientists
description: Applications of modern semiconductor devices to physical instrumentation. Characteristics of semiconductor devices, integrated circuits, analog and digital circuits.

title: Continuum Mechanics
description: Introduction to the continuum limit and stress and strain tensors. Hydrodynamics of perfect fluids; two-dimensional problems, motion of incompressible viscous fluids, Navier Stokes equations. Basic elasticity theory. Description of viscoelastic materials. Introduction to nonlinear behavior instabilities.

title: Numerical Methods
description: Introduction to theory and practice of modern numerical methods. Techniques are drawn from topics such as solution of differential equations, Monte Carlo methods, Fast Fourier transforms, and evaluation of special functions.

title: Electromagnetism
description: Maxwell's equations, electrodynamics, electromagnetic waves and radiation, wave propagation in media, interference and quantum optics, coherent and incoherent radiation, with practical applications in interferometry, lasers, waveguides, and optical instrumentation.

title: Computational Methods
description: Mathematical and numerical analysis using Mathematica and C programming, as applied to problems in physical science.

title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
description: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

title: Principles of Imaging
description: Linear systems, probability and random processes, image processing, projecting imaging, tomographic imaging.

title: Techniques in Medical Imaging I: X-ray, Nuclear, and NMR Imaging
description: Ionizing radiation, planar and tomographic radiographic and nuclear imaging, magnetism, NMR, MRI imaging.

title: Techniques in Medical Imaging II: Ultrasound, Electrophysiological, Optical
description: Sound and ultrasound, ultrasonic imaging, physiological electromagnetism, EEG, MEG, ECG, MCG, optical properties of tissues, fluorescence and bioluminescence, MR impedance imaging, MR spectroscopy, electron spin resonance and ESR imaging.

title: Elementary Particle Physics
description: Overview of Standard Model theory and phenomenology. Electromagnetic, strong and weak forces, quark model, interactions with matter, particle detectors and accelerators.

title: Advanced Elementary Particle Physics
description: SU(3)xSU(2)xU(1) model of strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions. K-meson system and CP violation, neutrino masses and mixing, grand-unified theories, supersymmetry, introduction to cosmology and its connection to particle physics.

title: Advanced Elementary Particle Physics
description: SU(3)xSU(2)xU(1) model of strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions. K-meson system and CP violation, neutrino masses and mixing, grand-unified theories, supersymmetry, introduction to cosmology and its connection to particle physics.

title: Quantum Field Theory
description: Canonical quantization, scalar field theory, Feynman diagrams, tree-level quantum electrodynamics.

title: Advanced Quantum Field Theory
description: Pathintegral techniques, loop diagrams, regularization and renormalization, anomalies.

title: Condensed Matter Physics
description: Bonding in solids; crystal symmetry and group theory, elastic properties of crystals; lattice vibrations, interaction of radiation with matter; cohesion of solids; the electron gas; electron energy bands in solids; ferromagnetism; transport theory; semiconductors and superconductors; many-body perturbation theory.
prerequisite: PHYSICS 133 and (PHYSICS 214A or CHEM 232A) and (PHYSICS 215B or CHEM 231B)

title: Condensed Matter Physics
description: Bonding in solids; crystal symmetry and group theory, elastic properties of crystals; lattice vibrations, interaction of radiation with matter; cohesion of solids; the electron gas; electron energy bands in solids; ferromagnetism; transport theory; semiconductors and superconductors; many-body perturbation theory.

title: Condensed Matter Physics
description: Bonding in solids; crystal symmetry and group theory, elastic properties of crystals; lattice vibrations, interaction of radiation with matter; cohesion of solids; the electron gas; electron energy bands in solids; ferromagnetism; transport theory; semiconductors and superconductors; many-body perturbation theory.

title: Plasma Physics
description: Basic concepts, orbits, kinetic and fluid equations, Coulomb collisions, fluctuations, scattering, radiation.

title: Plasma Physics
description: Magnetic confinement, MHD equilibrium and stability, collisional transport.

title: Plasma Physics
description: Linear waves and instabilities, uniform un-magnetized and magnetized plasmas, non-uniform plasmas.

title: Galactic Astrophysics
description: The morphology, kinematics, and evolution of our Milky Way and other galaxies.  Topics include stellar formation and stellar evolution, end states of stars (supernovae, neutron stars), the distribution of stars, interstellar gas and mass in galaxies. The Local Group.

title: Cosmology
description: An introduction to modern cosmology set within the context of general relativity.  Topics include the expansion history of the Universe, inflation, the cosmic microwave background, density fluctuations, structure formation, dark matter, dark energy, and gravitational lensing.

title: Radiative Processes in Astrophysics
description: Exploration of radiation mechanisms (electron scattering, synchrotron emission, collisional excitation, and more) and radiative transfer through matter including absorption and emission. Includes such observational astrophysics topics as spectroscopic study of atoms and nuclei, X-rays, and cosmic rays.

title: Solar System and Extrasolar Planets
description: Formation, evolution, and habitability of planetary systems. Observational and theoretical study of the origin and evolution of the Solar System, present day dynamical state of the Solar System (asteroids, Kuiper Belt Objects, Oort cloud), planetary atmospheres, processes governing planetary climate.

title: Stellar Astrophysics
description: Physics of stellar interiors and equations of stellar structure. Stellar atmospheres and absorption processes. Introduction to stellar winds. Thermonuclear reactions, nucleosynthesis, and solar neutrinos. Binary stars and mass accretion. White dwarfs, supernovae, neutron stars, and black holes.

title: Extragalactic Astrophysics
description: The physics and phenomenology of galaxies; star formation, interstellar medium, and intergalactic medium.  Galaxy structure and dynamics.  Galaxy evolution, stellar populations, and scaling relations; the relationship between galaxy properties and environment.  Galaxy clusters and active galactic nuclei.

title: Early Universe Physics
description: Includes a thorough quantum treatment of the generation of perturbations during inflation and various topics related to kinetic theory in an expanding Universe.  Other topics include the astrophysics and cosmology of weakly interacting particles.

title: Astro Fundamentals
description: Introduction to topics in astrophysics including measurement of stellar properties, stellar structure and evolution, stellar remnants and supernovae, the interstellar medium, exoplanets, gravitational lensing, galactic structure, extragalactic distance measurements, and the expanding universe.

title: Special Topics in Astrophysics
description: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of astrophysics that is undergoing rapid development.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Special Topics in Particle Physics
description: Current topics in particle non-accelerator-based research fields.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Special Topics in Condensed Matter Physics
description: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of condensed matter physics that is undergoing rapid development.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

title: Special Topics in Plasma Physics
description: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of plasma physics that is undergoing rapid development.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Physics and Astronomy Communications Skills
description: Fundamentals of effectively communicating research through written and oral platforms. Topics include writing compelling proposals and journal articles for peer review, and the development of engaging oral presentations of science results and significance to a wide range of audiences.

title: General Relativity
description: An introduction to Einstein's theory of gravitation. Tensor analysis, Einstein's field equations, astronomical tests of Einstein's theory, gravitational waves.

title: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics
description: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics
description: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics
description: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
description: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.

title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
description: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.

title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
description: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.

title: Seminar in Particle Physics
description: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Particle Physics
description: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Particle Physics
description: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Astrophysics
description: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Astrophysics
description: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Astrophysics
description: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Current Topics in Chemical, Applied, and Materials Physics
description: The subjects covered vary from year to year.  Connection between fundamental principles and implementations in practice in science, industry, and technology.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Current Problems in Particle Physics
description: Presentation and discussion of current research and theory in particle physics.  Lectures given by staff and students.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Current Problems in Particle Physics
description: Presentation and discussion of current research and theory in particle physics.  Lectures given by staff and students.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Systems Microbiology Research
description: A research and journal club seminar that covers topics on bacteria and phage using approaches and principles from biology, engineering, and physics.
restriction: Upper-division students only. Graduate students only.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Teaching Physics
description: Techniques for effective teaching.  Covers active listening and student engagement, problem-solving skills, peer instruction and collaborative learning, and evaluation.  Required of all new Teaching Assistants.

title: Technical Communication Skills
description: Development of effective communication skills, oral and written presentations, through examples and practice.

title: Research Seminar
description: Detailed discussion of research problems of current interest in the Department.  Format, content, and frequency of the course are variable.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Experimental Research
description: With the approval of a faculty member, a student may pursue a research program in experimental physics.  Typical areas include astrophysics, condensed matter physics, elementary particle physics, and plasma physics.
restriction: Graduate students only. School of Physical Sciences students only.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Theoretical Research
description: With approval of a faculty member, a student may pursue a research program in theoretical physics. Typical areas include astrophysics, condensed matter physics, elementary particle physics, and plasma physics.
restriction: Graduate students only. School of Physical Sciences students only.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Physics Colloquium
description: Seminar held each week, in which a current research topic is explored. Frequently, off-campus researchers are invited to present the seminar, and on occasion a faculty member or researcher from the Department will speak.
restriction: School of Physical Sciences students only.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Reading of Special Topic
description: With special consent from a faculty member who will agree to supervise the program, a student may receive course credit for individual study of some area of physics.

title: Laboratory Teaching
description: Required of and limited to teaching assistants of undergraduate laboratory courses. Designed to teach the  necessary skills required of teaching assistants for these courses.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: University Teaching
description: Required of and limited to Teaching Assistants.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
